results.title: Stella does tricks
results.creator_credit: Coky Giedroyc, Adam Barker, Channel Four Television, British Film Institute, Sidewalk Productions and Compulsive Films
results.brief_description: Having escaped Glasgow and the sexual abuse of the father she once adored, Stella winds up on the streets of London as a teenage prostitute with a vicious middle-aged pimp. Despite her bleak and seemingly hopeless circumstances, a streak of anger and yearning drives her to escape the sadistic men who dominate her life, but not before her pimp exacts one last act of savage abuse. The film shifts abruptly between Stella’s romanticised interior world of memories and fantasies, and the real world where her rage erupts into acts of vandalism and often poetic revenge on the men who have mistreated her. Giedroyc draws on her former experience as a director of realist drama and documentary for British television, handling the often confronting subject matter frankly and suffusing the film with a sense of outrage and urgency. Cast includes Kelly Macdonald, James Bolam, Hans Matheson and Ewan Stewart.

results.title: Stella Dallas
results.creator_credit: King Vidor, Samuel Goldwyn and Samuel Goldwyn Co
results.brief_description: Barbara Stanwyck gives one of her best performances as a social-climbing mother from the wrong side of the tracks. Born a mill-hand’s daughter with no social graces, an ill-fated marriage leaves Stella single-handedly raising her daughter Laurel (Anne Shirley). Stella dreams of a new life for her daughter until she realises that what stands between Laurel and her dreams is Stella herself. This is a memorable and heartbreaking tale of a mother’s love and ultimate sacrifice - with one of Hollywood’s greatest finales. Don’t watch this film without a box of tissues. Also stars John Boles, Barbara O’Neil and Alan Hale. Based upon the novel by Olive Higgins Prouty.

results.title: Stelarc: an interview at the N.T.U. Fine Arts Department, Darwin, Australia
results.creator_credit: Mary Jane Overall and Northern Territory University
results.brief_description: Stelarc is a unique performance artist, internationally renown for “events” he stages. In these, he suspends his nude body with fish hooks in various situations or uses a bionic arm and helmet which give him laser eyes. These live works of art, with the use of technology are shockingly magnificent in their audacity and innovation. This in-depth interview conducted in 1991, features footage and photographs from the various Stelarc “events”, and reveals the reasons and ideas behind them. Stelarc’s curiousity and vision have enabled him to make some unusual predicitions about the future of human kind.

results.title: Steel challenge
results.creator_credit: Robin Cantelon, A. Frank Bundy, Pat Morton and Wallace Productions
results.brief_description: Demonstrates the widespread use of the latest scientific techniques in steelmaking. As an example of this progress the changeover from open hearth to electric steelmaking is examined. Deals with the computer control of electric power, methods of quality control and improvements to steelmaking practice.

results.title: Steamboat Bill Jr. (Musical Soundtrack)
results.creator_credit: Charles Reisner and Buster Keaton Productions
results.brief_description:
Set in the Deep South with Keaton as the wimpish son of a steamboat captain who ultimately proves himself in helping his father fight off a wealthy rival. Particularly memorable is the hat-buying sequence and the remarkably staged cyclone sequence in which the town is destroyed around a stoic Buster. Version without musical soundtrack also available on 16mm.

Credits: Director, Chas F. Reisner ; photographers, Dev Jennings, Bert Haines ; writers, Carl Harbaugh, Buster Keaton ; piano accompaniment, William Perry.
Cast: Buster Keaton, Tom McGuire, Ernest Torrence, Tom Lewis, Marion Byron.

results.title: Steam days: Travels with a Duchess and the fishing line
results.creator_credit: Neil Cameron, Peter Walton and BBC
results.brief_description: Presented by Miles Kington, dedicated enthusiast, this celebration of the steam age looks at some of the great British engines, travels the famous lines and meets the wonderfully eccentric people who keep steam alive in Britain today. “Travels with a Duchess” looks at The Duchess of Hamilton, one of the most famous passenger trains built in the 1930s. “The Fishing Line” travels the fishing line from Fort William to Malliag, built to transport herring at the end of the nineteenth century.

results.title: Steam days 2
results.creator_credit: Peter Walton, Neil Cameron and BBC-TV
results.brief_description: Another delightful program for lovers of steam trains and travel. Two episodes featured. “Workhorses” covers the history of steam freight trains in Britain. Miles Kington reflects fondly on the unsung heroes of the railways. “Going Great Western” takes us on the Great Western Railway, which opened the so-called Cornish Riviera to travellers in the Victorian era. Features beautiful West Country scenery.

results.title: Steam at war: the home front
results.brief_description: Using footage from three classic wartime railway short films- ‘Carrying the Load’, ‘Necessary Journey’ and ‘Southern on Service’, this tape profiles Britain’s railways during the tumultuous Second World War. It covers a gamut of wartime operations, including troop and freight trains carrying men and munitions, Luftwaffe raids on railways, mobile hospital carriages, rail mounted anti-aircraft guns on the Romney, Hythe and Dymchurch narrow-gauge railway, the naming ceremony of the ‘Home Guard’ loco, plus many other memorable moments. Also included on the tape is exclusive footage of the North Yorkshire Moors Railway ‘Steam at War’ weekend. A weekend which is noted for its recreation of the sights and sounds of wartime steam on the home front.

results.title: Steam alive in Victoria: a tribute to steam
results.brief_description: The history of Victoria’s steam trains runs parallel to the history of the state itself. As the railway tracks made their way into the countryside, the state began to develop. Steam locomotives puffing their way into country towns were the life blood of the state, bringing in supplies and visitors and taking away produce and goods. Today the steam locomotives have been replaced. Many were left to rust and decay but a number of them have been restored by dedicated groups of volunteers, determined to preserve this exciting part of our heritage. Steam trains are alive again in Victoria and this magnificent videotape is a tribute to those groups who have kept the locomotives on the tracks to give pleasure to those who love steam travel. You can enjoy the thrill of the journey, the heat of the firebox and the shrill of the whistle as you watch “Steam Alive in Victoria”.

results.title: Steam across the mountains: the story of the Zig Zag Railway
results.creator_credit: Nick A'Hern, ABC Video and Nick A'Hern Productions
results.brief_description: The Zig Zag Railway is regarded as an engineering marvel and a mecca to students of engineering the world over. This fascinating video follows the Zig Zag’s colourful history from its early days in the great commercial steam era, to its closure in 1910 and through to its restoration as a tourist railway in 1975. This program uses the Zig Zag Railway as a working model to bring to life the romance adventure and style of the Great Australian Steam Era. Highlights include: complete stereo soundtrack, breathtaking footage shot entirely on 16mm film and loads of steam trains to see and hear!
